Home.title: Milad Akbari
Home.subtitle: Building Europe's leading EV auction platform
Home.introBased: based in Munich. Previously, I worked at
Home.introYears: I've been coding for 5+ years, mainly in the TypeScript and Python.
Home.paragraph2: Most developers pick a side. I never could. I'd be deep in a NestJS module, perfectly happy, then wander over to a Next.js component and lose an hour on details that didn't need to be that good. I love the moment when a well-typed NestJS service shakes hands with a Langchain and LangGraph workflow and something genuinely useful comes to life.
Home.closing: I spend most of my time learning new frameworks I swore I'd never learn, reading documentation and blogs that were written three hours ago, trying to convince myself I actually need to learn another JavaScript framework.

Beliefs.title: Things I Believe
Beliefs.shippingFast: Shipping fast beats the best strategy
Beliefs.aiNativeRest: teams will move 10x faster than those not willing to change
Beliefs.landingsLaunches: Landings > launches (i.e. product adoption > shipping code)
Beliefs.listenBuildShip: Listen, build, ship, tell the customer, then repeat forever
Beliefs.changeMind: You can just change your mind if wrong
Beliefs.collectiveTruth: Seek the collective truth, not just one opinion
Beliefs.everyoneWriter: Everyone (yes, you) needs to become a
Beliefs.leadersClarity: Leaders step up to provide clarity when absent
Beliefs.takingNotes: Be the person taking notes, even if it's just for yourself
Beliefs.slackProTip: Slack pro tip: anticipate objections before hitting send, then
Beliefs.educationMarketing: Education is the best form of developer marketing
Beliefs.authenticFailures: Be authentic and own your failures
Beliefs.neverWebinar: Never use the word "webinar" ever again
Beliefs.leadershipOutcomes: Leadership means owning outcomes beyond the org chart
Beliefs.leadersWork: Leaders have to do the work themselves and delegate
Beliefs.writePlaybook: You can write your own playbook
Beliefs.studyOthers: Study what worked for others, then take your own path
Beliefs.workHobby: Work can also be your hobby
Beliefs.otherHobbies: This doesn't mean you can't have other hobbies
Beliefs.curiosity: Your best work comes from following your curiosity
Beliefs.v0Prototype: You could have built a prototype in v0 during the meeting
Beliefs.hiringLeaders: Hiring is what separates good leaders from great
Beliefs.hireLearnFrom: Hire people you can learn from
Beliefs.hireWorkFor: Hire people you would someday be happy working for
Beliefs.interviewQuestion: Favorite interview question: what work are you most proud of?
Beliefs.assumeGoodIntent: Always try to assume good intent
Beliefs.badDay: They might just be having a bad day

Bio.title: My life in five minutes
Bio.paragraph1: My parents, and later the internet, taught me I could build anything.
Bio.paragraph2Prefix: I was five years old when I saw
Bio.paragraph2Suffix: 1999) in theaters. It's about a kid inspired by the launch of Sputnik, who takes up rocketry against his father's wishes.
Bio.spoilersTitle: Spoilers: Watch the ending of October Sky
Bio.spoilersContent: Homer wins the science fair and earns a scholarship. He goes on to work for NASA as an engineer.
Bio.paragraph3: I was enamored with rockets, and unlike Homer's dad in the film, my dad bought me my first model rocket set. My parents started and ran a construction business for over 40 years.
Bio.paragraph4: I wanted to understand every piece of that rocket. Why were there different body shapes? How were the engines made? Could we make even bigger rockets?
Bio.paragraph5: I didn't know it at the time, but I was going to be an engineer. This obsession with building things continued throughout my childhood.

Feedback.title: How to respond to angry feedback
Feedback.intro: Here's how I recommend responding to customer feedback:
Feedback.closing: And finally, sometimes you need to post through it. Remember, not everyone is going to like you.
Feedback.inspiredBy: (Some of these are inspired by Lulu from Rostra)

items.notEveryone: Accept that not everyone will like you.
items.turnOffReplies: If you turn off replies on a post, you already lost.
items.noHumor: Don't use humor or sarcasm when they're upset.
items.noCorpospeak: Don't use "corpospeak". Speak plainly, without jargon.
items.admitUnknown: If you don't know the answer, admit it and say what you're doing to find out.
items.feelHeard: Make people feel heard. Behind almost every frustrated customer is real, helpful feedback.
items.kindEmpathetic: Be kind and empathetic when responding to negative feedback. Even if they don't deserve it.
items.dontReject: Don't reject feedback. You're saying they're wrong, which makes them defend themselves.
items.writePublic: Write in public for the secondary audience, not the antagonistic user.
items.explainDontDefend: Explain, don't defend. You can say the exact same thing in a way that sounds bitter or sounds transparent.
items.takeResponsibility: Take more responsibility than seems necessary. Take so much ownership that it surprises people.
items.narrative: Everything you post either helps or hurts a narrative. Sometimes there can be value in responding carefully if it plays well to spectators.
items.bragging: If you present yourself in a way that makes people believe you are bragging or cocky, they will be more likely to try and knock you down a peg.
items.technicalTopics: When discussing deeply technical topics, be exceptionally detailed in your response. Be calm, factual, and empathetic to their concerns.
items.apologize: If you apologize, fully commit. State the problem, explain the fix, share what you're doing to prevent it. But only apologize if you truly believe it.
